docs.title: Embedded Applications
docs.text: Learning bare-metal programming through apps and projects.

docs.title: About
docs.text: This repository contains my projects and experiments in embedded systems, focusing on low-level / bare-metal programming. It includes small applications or test programs.

docs.title: Counter App
docs.text: This project is a simple counter application using a 7-segment display and two buttons on an AVR microcontroller.

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
• 7-segment display shows digits from 0 to 9.
  • Button 1: Cycles through the digits (0 → 1 → … → 9 → 0).
  • Button 2: Turns off the display (all segments off).

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This project monitors ambient temperature and light levels using sensors and displays the data on a 16x2 LCD. Users can set thresholds and control a DC motor via buttons. A LED simulates a light, turning on when the ambient light falls below the set threshold. UART interface allows testing and data reading from a PC.

docs.title: Components
docs.text:
• ATmega2560 microcontroller
  • LM35 temperature sensor (analog)
  • Light-dependent resistor (LDR)
  • 16x2 LCD with I2C interface
  • 3 push-buttons (navigation, select)
  • Status LED
  • DC motor controlled via PWM
  • UART interface for testing and monitoring

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Interactive LCD menu: navigate with buttons to set temperature/light thresholds and motor status/speed.
  • Automatic control:
  • Motor turns on if temperature exceeds threshold.
  • LED lights up when light level is below threshold.
  • UART commands for testing and data monitoring:
  • normal_mode → stream sensor data to PC
  • test_mode → stop streaming and test components (test_led, test_temp, test_lcd, test_motor)

docs.title: Motor Control
docs.text:
• PWM signal via hardware timer
  • Motor speed adjustable from menu

docs.title: LED Control
docs.text:
• Lights up when LDR value is below threshold
  • Can be tested via UART

docs.title: App 1
docs.text:
Requirement: perform the alternate blink of odd and even LEDs of the bargraph

Cycle this infinitely.

A: LEDs that have even indexes. B: LEDs that have odd indexes.

The time between sequences is 500 milliseconds.

docs.title: App 2
docs.text:
Requirement: turn on the first two LEDs of the bargraph and then "move" them right LED by LED

Cycle this infinitely.

The time between each "move" is 500 milliseconds.

Extra: At the end shift them in opposite direction.

docs.title: App 1
docs.text: There are two LEDs and one BUTTON. Each 3 seconds, the first LED (LED0) will be toggled. In parallel, if the BUTTON is pressed, the second LED (LED1) will be turned ON and when the BUTTON is released, the LED1 will be turned OFF.

docs.title: App 2
docs.text:
Use two buttons to command 4 LEDs. Initially, all 4 LEDs will be powered-on. If the first button will be pressed, all the LEDs will be turned OFF. After this, if the second button will be pressed, all the LEDs will be turned ON.

If in the initially state, the second button will be pressed, the LEDs will remain turned ON.
